ability to do it per module and also have a toggle for the whole template. Honestly, portal wide would even be good to but i can see that becoming problematic
how easy is coding on a tablet anyway?
easy when you use codeanywhere

I once troubleshooted and fixed a site that was down using just my phone while out camping out in the middle of nowhere with only a few bars of signal by using codeanywhere, had the site fixed in 5-10 minutes, didn’t even have to get up from my comfy camping chair next to the cozy firepit.

that alone made me realize the value of making all of these tools responsive.

There was a time when I didn’t have a car, and I was taking the bus to get to work. was really awesome to be able to work on stuff right on the bus using the bus’s wifi and codeanywhere on my phone. Made it so in the time it took to ride to work I could have a small project done or an issue fixed.

it’s why I refer to myself as device agnostic.

I’ve moved pretty much everything to the cloud. I can happily work on any random device and be productive, even if it’s not my device.
yes <@U7SL518D6> I feel you :wink:

look at all that talent

So putting this out here for other developers that might run into the same issue.
**Scenario:**
In a `Rich Text` field for an email, pre-populating a link's href attribute with a contact property.
ie: a Go-to-Webinar URL

**Issue:**
1. The Personalization token markup generated would need to be edited in the source cause `""` inside of the `href=" "` attribute is incorrect markup.
incorrect: `<a href="{{ personalization_token("contact.webinar_link", "") }}">Some Link</a>`
correct: `<a href="{{ personalization_token('contact.webinar_link', '') }}">Some Link</a>`
2. However, while editing in the WYSIWYG view, if someone clicks that link and the Personalization token is written out as the "correct" form above, the URL field gets prepended with a temporary url such as: `https://<email_domain>/-temporary-slug-<some_generated_number>`
This could cause some large issue with clients if an editor doesn't notice that change had occurred.
3. After doing some more testing, it looks like just using the basic Hubl markup for a contact property does not cause this and still populates correctly (as long as the contact property is filled out):
example: `<a href="{{ contact.webinar_link }}">Some Link</a>`

Hopefully this is helpful for those of us that deal with emails and dynamic properties like this.
:slightly_smiling_face: Got the module from the marketplace … it uses insafeed.js … just like my module :slightly_smiling_face:
